awd_titl_txt: Modeling Aqueous Secondary Organic Aerosol Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to develop a better understanding of chemical processes occurring in cloud droplets and wet atmospheric particles that can lead to the formation of secondary small particles in the atmosphere.  A model will be applied to data collected in the field in 2013 during the Southern Oxidant and Aerosol Study to evaluate the fate of natural emissions to the atmosphere. This research effort will improve the understanding of factors that influence the formation of small particles through processing in cloud droplets and aerosol liquid water, hence leading to improved models of atmospheric chemistry, air quality and climate.

State-of-the-art modeling approaches will be used to evaluate the formation of aqueous Secondary Organic Aerosol (aqSOA) and their impacts on aerosol mass, composition, and optical properties. Aqueous processing allows SOA formation from highly volatile species, including oxidation products of isoprene, such as glyoxal and isoprene epoxydiols (IEPOX).  A photochemical box model, Gas-Aerosol Model for Mechanism Analysis (GAMMA) and its simplified version (simpleGAMMA), will be applied to analyses of field data using limited gas-phase tracer inputs. SimpleGAMMA was developed to be computationally efficient and suitable for coupling with larger-scale atmospheric chemistry models.

A detailed intercomparison will be conducted of the SimpleGAMMA aqueous aerosol SOA formation scheme and other SOA formation schemes, such as the IEPOX SOA scheme from the Community Multi-scale Air Quality (CMAQ) model. The PI will also introduce or update aqSOA formation schemes in several 3D regional and global models including GEOS-Chem, GISS ModelIE2 Earth System Model, and WRF-Chem. This work will result in improved prognostic capabilities for atmospheric chemistry models.

por.por_cntn:
The work supported by this award has advanced our understanding of multiphase processes in the atmosphere, and enabled their representation in large scale models of atmopsheric chemistry and climate. We used the McNeill Group atmospheric multiphase chemistry models GAMMA and simpleGAMMA, and parameterizations developed from those models, to analyze data from the Southern Oxidant and Aerosol Study (SOAS 2013) and the results were published and featured in conference presentations (e.g., Budisulistiorini et al. 2015 and 2017, Marais et al. 2016, Li et al. 2016, Mao et al. 2018). This work included a model intercomparison with the aqueous SOA scheme in CMAQ (Budisulistiorini et al. 2015, 2017). We worked with Dr. Manishkumar Shrivastava to introduce aqueous aerosol SOA formation into WRF-Chem using simpleGAMMA, which was then applied to analyze SOA formation in the Amazon (Nature Communications 2019).  We also developed a parameterization of oxidative aqueous SOA formation from glyoxal and methylglyoxal for application in global models (Curry et al. 2018). This is currently being implemented into GEOS-Chem, CMAQ, and WRF-Chem. We participated in a box model intercomparison study for cloud-aerosol multiphase chemistry models centered on the Whiteface Mountain pilot study (Barth et al., in prep 2020). We pioneered a lab-to-environment modeling approach using GAMMA to screen lab discoveries in atmospheric chemistry for environmental impact and potential inclusion in large-scale models (e.g., Tsui et al. 2017, Tsui and McNeill 2018). Finally, extensive model development was performed, from updating the oxidant and aqueous organic chemistry and gas-phase chemistry, introducing cloud modeling, transition metal ion chemistry, sulfur chemistry, and dynamic tracking of aerosol acidity, testing the impact of photosensitizer chemistry on SOA formation, and more (Tsui et al. 2017, 2018, 2019, Wang 2019, Pye et al. 2019). Outreach activities associated with the project have promoted public understanding of atmopsheric chemistry and air quality issues with blog and social media content in English and Spanish.
